subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Macbeth
msgSnippet: ... A good place to start might be the Shavian Letter Frequency Analysis for Scott s Shavian Documents
messageBody:
> I am not sure, but I thought there was somebody discussing about a
> corpus of normal modern texts, so we could find out which sounds
> occur the most (either here, on the shavian group or on the
> alt.language.artificial newsgroup). the schwa 'a' and the letter n
> are probably numbers one and two, but I need to know the ones after
> number 26.
>
A good place to start might be the Shavian Letter Frequency Analysis
for Scott's Shavian Documents
<http://www.mithrandir.com/Shavian/ShavianFrequencyCount.html>. The
frequency analysis covers the texts transliterated by Scott Harrison
available at his site
<http://www.mithrandir.com/Shavian/Shavian.html>.

The sample size is ~150,000 characters, so the trends should be
clear. Surprisingly, schwa (ado) is 7th on the list. Perhaps this is
due to a bias of the author's spelling?... Here's the (pruned) list:

9.18% Nun
9.07% Tot
8.24% If
6.56% So
5.40% Dead
5.17% Loll
4.96% Ado
4.19% THey
...
...
0.33% Yea
0.00% Ah


With the appropriate corpus of texts, the frequency analysis should
be fairly simple. A simple Perl script would do the job (perl -e
'while(<>){chomp; for(split/\s*/){$f{$_}++}} for(keys %f) { print "$_ =
$f{$_} \n"; }')....

Regards,

Brian Roberts

  The sample size is ~150,000 characters, so the trends should be
clear.  Surprisingly, schwa (ado) is 7th on the list.  Perhaps this is
due to a bias of the author's spelling?...  Here's the (pruned) list:

   9.18%  Nun

   With the appropriate corpus of texts, the frequency analysis should
